pm_simulator.title: PM Simulator - Empowerment Scenarios
pm_simulator.description: Face realistic project scenarios involving empowerment, delegation, and team autonomy. For each situation, choose the best response.

scenarios.title: The Bottleneck PM
scenarios.situation:
You've been managing a software development project for six months. Your team of eight experienced developers has a strong track record. However, you've noticed that decisions are piling up waiting for your approval‚Äîtechnical approach choices, tool selections, process adjustments. Team members often wait 1-2 days for your response because you're in meetings. Sprint velocity has dropped 20% over the past two sprints.

During the retrospective, the tech lead says: "We spend more time waiting for approvals than actually building. We know what we're doing‚Äîwe just need permission to do it."
scenarios.question: What should you do?
options: Acknowledge the feedback and commit to faster response times on approval requests
Create a decision rights matrix that defines which decisions the team can make independently, which require informing you, and which need your approval
Delegate all technical decisions to the tech lead so there's a single point of contact
Schedule daily decision meetings where the team can get rapid approvals on pending items
scenarios.explanation:
The root cause isn't slow approvals‚Äîit's unnecessary approvals. An experienced team shouldn't need PM permission for most technical decisions. Option B addresses this systemically by creating clear boundaries: team decides X independently, informs you of Y, and escalates Z. This eliminates the bottleneck while maintaining appropriate oversight for high-impact decisions.

Option A treats the symptom (slow response) not the disease (unnecessary approvals). Option C over-concentrates authority in one person. Option D institutionalizes the bottleneck rather than removing it.
scenarios.key_principle: Define decision rights explicitly. Don't require approval for decisions the team is qualified to make.

scenarios.title: The Nervous New Hire
scenarios.situation:
Marcus joined your team three weeks ago as a junior business analyst. He has relevant education but limited practical experience. You assigned him to gather requirements for a small module‚Äîsomething manageable for his skill level.

Marcus has been asking questions constantly‚Äîsometimes 8-10 times per day. Questions range from "Should I use this template?" to "Is it okay to schedule a meeting with this stakeholder?" to "What format should the document be?" Your other team members are starting to get pulled into answering his questions too.

Yesterday, Marcus said: "I just want to make sure I'm doing everything right. I don't want to mess anything up."
scenarios.question: What should you do?
options: Tell Marcus he's empowered to make these decisions himself and should only come to you with significant issues
Pair Marcus with a senior BA who can provide guidance and gradually transfer decision-making to him
Create detailed documentation of exactly how tasks should be done so Marcus has clear guidance
Have a conversation with Marcus about which decisions he can make independently and which warrant checking in
scenarios.explanation:
Marcus is at the "low competence, high commitment" stage (D1 in Situational Leadership). He needs direction‚Äîbut constant PM direction isn't sustainable. Pairing him with a senior BA provides the guidance he needs while building his capability and confidence over time. The senior BA can progressively transfer decision authority as Marcus demonstrates competence.

Option A gives too much autonomy too fast‚Äîhe'll either freeze or make avoidable mistakes. Option C creates dependency on documentation rather than building judgment. Option D is partially right but doesn't provide the ongoing support structure Marcus needs.
scenarios.key_principle: Match delegation level to capability. New team members need more direction initially, with progressive empowerment as they demonstrate competence.

scenarios.title: The Micromanaged Expert
scenarios.situation:
Priya is your most experienced developer with 12 years of expertise in the exact technology stack your project uses. She's consistently delivered high-quality work and has saved the project multiple times with her deep technical knowledge.

Recently, your organization implemented a new governance process requiring PM approval on all technical design decisions. You've been reviewing Priya's designs and approving them without changes‚Äîthey're always solid. But the review cycle adds 2-3 days to each decision.

Priya requests a meeting and says: "I understand the new process, but I feel like I'm being treated like a junior developer. You approve everything I submit without changes. Can we find a different approach?"
scenarios.question: What should you do?
options: Explain that the governance process applies to everyone equally and you can't make exceptions
Propose to leadership that proven senior technical staff be exempt from the approval requirement for decisions within their expertise
Continue the approval process but commit to 24-hour turnaround to minimize delays
Ask Priya to document her decisions more thoroughly so leadership has visibility without requiring approval
scenarios.explanation:
Priya is right‚Äîthe process doesn't match her capability level. When approvals are rubber-stamps, they add delay without value. The PM's role includes advocating for appropriate processes. Proposing an exemption for proven experts (with clear criteria) addresses the legitimate governance concern while empowering capable professionals.

Option A enforces a process that's demonstrably inappropriate for this situation. Option C reduces but doesn't eliminate unnecessary friction. Option D adds work for Priya without addressing the authority mismatch.
scenarios.key_principle: Advocate for empowerment. When processes prevent capable people from being effective, work to change the processes.

scenarios.title: The Self-Organizing Struggle
scenarios.situation:
Your Scrum team has been together for four months. They're technically capable but haven't fully embraced self-organization. During sprint planning, they look to you to assign tasks. In daily standups, they report to you rather than each other. When problems arise, they wait for you to solve them.

You've tried saying "You decide" and "The team should figure this out," but they seem uncomfortable and decisions take longer when you step back.

The Scrum Master mentions: "They're used to being told what to do. They have the skills, but not the confidence to own decisions."
scenarios.question: What should you do?
options: Continue directing the team since that's what they're comfortable with and it's more efficient
Force self-organization by refusing to make any decisions and requiring the team to figure everything out
Gradually transfer decision authority by starting with low-risk decisions, celebrating successes, and expanding scope over time
Send the team to agile training so they understand how self-organizing teams are supposed to work
scenarios.explanation:
The team is in transition‚Äîthey have capability but lack confidence in self-organization. This requires a gradual approach: start with decisions where failure is low-cost, let them experience success, build confidence, then expand. Forcing immediate self-organization (Option B) will create anxiety and poor decisions. Continuing to direct (Option A) perpetuates dependency.

Option D assumes knowledge is the gap‚Äîbut they likely understand self-organization conceptually; they lack experience and confidence in practice.
scenarios.key_principle: Build self-organization progressively. Start small, celebrate wins, expand authority as confidence grows.

scenarios.title: The Authority Gap
scenarios.situation:
You assigned Chen to lead the vendor integration workstream. He's accountable for delivering the integration on time and within budget. However, Chen keeps running into obstacles:

- He can't approve vendor invoices over $5,000 (most are $8,000-15,000)
- He can't access the production environment to verify integration points
- He can't schedule meetings with the vendor's technical team without going through procurement
- He can't make scope decisions without your approval

Chen is frustrated: "You made me responsible for this, but I can't actually do anything without asking permission. I spend more time getting approvals than doing the work."
scenarios.question: What should you do?
options: Acknowledge the constraints and commit to faster approvals to reduce Chen's delays
Work with finance, IT, and procurement to get Chen the access and authority he needs to fulfill his accountability
Take back ownership of the vendor integration since the organizational constraints make delegation impractical
Escalate to your sponsor that organizational processes are blocking project progress
scenarios.explanation:
This is a classic "responsibility without authority" failure. Chen was given accountability but not the matching authority. The PM's job is to fix this‚Äîwork across the organization to get Chen what he needs. This might mean temporary spending authority, system access, and direct vendor contact rights.

Option A doesn't solve the problem‚Äîit just makes the PM a faster bottleneck. Option C gives up on empowerment rather than fixing the setup. Option D might be needed eventually, but first try to solve it at your level.
scenarios.key_principle: Responsibility must come with authority. If someone is accountable for results, ensure they have the power to achieve those results.

scenarios.title: The Stakeholder Bypass
scenarios.situation:
Your team has been empowered to make technical decisions within their domain. You've communicated this to stakeholders and it's been working well for two months.

However, a senior VP has started coming directly to you with technical questions and requests. When you redirect her to the technical lead (Jamal), she says: "I'd rather deal with the PM. Can't you just tell me?"

You've noticed that when the VP does talk to Jamal, she sometimes overrides his recommendations and tells him what to do. Jamal mentioned: "I don't feel like I have real authority. The VP just goes around me anyway."
scenarios.question: What should you do?
options: Handle the VP's requests yourself since she's senior and her preference should be accommodated
Have a private conversation with the VP explaining the team's decision authority and asking her to work through Jamal for technical matters
Attend meetings with Jamal and the VP to provide support and ensure the VP respects his authority
Escalate to your sponsor that the VP is undermining team empowerment
scenarios.explanation:
The PM must protect team authority. A direct, respectful conversation with the VP is the appropriate first step. Explain the reasoning (faster decisions, Jamal's expertise, team ownership) and ask for her partnership. Most executives will respect clear boundaries when the rationale is explained.

Option A undermines the empowerment you established. Option C creates a crutch rather than solving the issue. Option D escalates before attempting direct resolution.
scenarios.key_principle: Defend team authority. When stakeholders bypass empowered team members, redirect them and reinforce the team's decision rights.

scenarios.title: The Failed Delegation
scenarios.situation:
Two weeks ago, you delegated ownership of the testing strategy to Sam, a senior QA engineer. You told him: "You own this‚Äîmake it happen." You've been focused on other priorities and haven't checked in.

Today, you learned that the testing strategy is significantly behind. Sam made several decisions that created problems:
- He chose a testing tool that doesn't integrate with your CI/CD pipeline
- He committed to test coverage levels the team can't achieve in the timeline
- He didn't coordinate with developers on testability requirements

Sam is defensive: "You said I owned it. I made the decisions I thought were right."
scenarios.question: What should you do?
options: Take back ownership of the testing strategy and fix the problems yourself
Hold Sam accountable for the failures and document the performance issue
Acknowledge that you didn't provide enough context and support, work with Sam to course-correct, and establish better checkpoints going forward
Keep Sam in the lead role but review all his decisions before implementation going forward
scenarios.explanation:
This is a delegation failure, not a Sam failure. "You own this‚Äîmake it happen" without context, boundaries, or checkpoints is abdication, not delegation. Sam didn't know about CI/CD requirements, timeline constraints, or the need to coordinate with developers because you didn't tell him.

The right response: own your part, fix it together, and establish proper delegation structure (clear expectations, defined boundaries, appropriate checkpoints) for the path forward.

Option A punishes Sam for your setup failure. Option B blames Sam unfairly. Option D swings to micromanagement rather than proper delegation.
scenarios.key_principle: Delegation requires setup. When delegation fails, examine whether you provided clear expectations, necessary context, appropriate boundaries, and reasonable checkpoints.

scenarios.title: The Empowerment Success
scenarios.situation:
Six months ago, your team struggled with dependency on PM decisions. Through deliberate effort‚Äîdefining decision rights, progressive delegation, celebrating autonomous decisions‚Äîthe team has transformed. They now:

- Self-assign work during sprint planning
- Make technical decisions without PM approval
- Resolve most conflicts internally
- Proactively identify and address risks
- Deliver consistently with high quality

Your role has shifted to stakeholder management, obstacle removal, and strategic planning. The team rarely needs you for day-to-day decisions.

Your manager asks: "The team seems to run itself. What exactly do you do now?"
scenarios.question: How should you respond?
options: Explain that you've worked yourself out of the day-to-day by building a high-performing, self-organizing team‚Äîand that's exactly the goal
Start being more visible in team activities so leadership sees your involvement
Take on additional project responsibilities to demonstrate your value
Document all the behind-the-scenes work you do so leadership understands your contribution
scenarios.explanation:
This is empowerment success! A PM who builds a self-organizing team and focuses on strategic work is doing exactly what they should. Be confident in articulating this: "I've built a team that doesn't need me for daily decisions. That frees me to focus on stakeholder alignment, risk management, and removing organizational obstacles. The team's performance is the evidence of effective leadership."

Option B undermines the empowerment you built. Option C might be appropriate but isn't the answer to this question. Option D is defensive rather than confident.
scenarios.key_principle: Empowerment success means less visible PM involvement. A quiet PM with a high-performing team is doing it right.

lightning_round.title: Lightning Round - Empowerment Questions
lightning_round.description: Answer 25 rapid-fire questions about empowerment, delegation, and team autonomy. Questions are organized into 5 rounds of 5 questions each.

questions.question: A project manager assigns a task to a team member but doesn't give them access to the systems needed to complete it. What empowerment element is missing?
questions.explanation: Authority includes the resources, access, and decision rights needed to complete assigned work. Responsibility without matching authority sets people up for failure.

questions.question: In a RACI matrix, how many people should be assigned as "Accountable" for a single task?
questions.explanation: There must be exactly ONE person Accountable per task. Multiple accountable parties means no one truly owns the outcome. "When everyone is accountable, no one is accountable."

questions.question: A highly experienced team member asks the PM for approval on a routine technical decision they've made successfully many times before. What should the PM do?
options: Approve the decision to maintain the relationship
Empower them to make these decisions independently going forward
Ask why they need approval for something routine
Document the pattern and address it in their performance review
questions.explanation: This signals unnecessary dependency. The PM should break the pattern by explicitly delegating authority for routine decisions the team member has proven capable of handling.

questions.question: What is the difference between delegation and abdication?
options: Delegation involves senior staff; abdication involves junior staff
Delegation maintains accountability; abdication abandons it
Delegation is formal; abdication is informal
Delegation is temporary; abdication is permanent
questions.explanation: Delegation transfers authority while maintaining appropriate oversight and accountability. Abdication is abandoning responsibility‚Äî"figure it out yourself" with no support, no checkpoints, no accountability structure.

questions.question: According to Situational Leadership, what delegation approach is best for a team member with high competence and high commitment?
questions.explanation: High competence + high commitment = D4 in Situational Leadership. This person is ready for full delegation‚Äîthey have both the skill and motivation to own outcomes independently.

questions.question: In an agile environment, who decides HOW the work will be done?
questions.explanation: Self-organizing teams own the "how." The Product Owner decides WHAT to build (priority), but the team decides HOW to build it, including task distribution, technical approach, and process.

questions.question: A stakeholder asks the PM to assign specific tasks to individual developers during sprint planning. What should the PM do?
options: Assign tasks based on each developer's strengths
Explain that the team self-assigns work and facilitate that process
Ask the team if they prefer PM assignment or self-assignment
Compromise by assigning critical tasks and letting the team assign the rest
questions.explanation: Agile teams self-organize. The PM should protect this principle by explaining it to stakeholders and facilitating team-based task selection rather than imposing assignments.

questions.question: A mature Scrum team wants to change their Definition of Done. What should the Scrum Master do?
options: Approve the change if it maintains quality standards
Reject the change to maintain consistency
Support the team in making this decision themselves
Escalate to the Product Owner for approval
questions.explanation: The Definition of Done belongs to the team. A mature, self-organizing team should own their quality standards. The Scrum Master supports but doesn't approve or reject‚Äîthe team decides.

questions.question: What is the PM's primary role with a high-performing, self-organizing team?
questions.explanation: With self-organizing teams, the PM shifts from directing to enabling. Primary focus becomes removing organizational obstacles, managing stakeholder relationships, and handling strategic issues‚Äînot daily task direction.

questions.question: A team has been together for two months and is technically capable, but they still wait for PM direction on most decisions. What stage of self-organization are they likely in?
questions.explanation: Dependent teams wait for direction even when capable. They haven't yet developed confidence in autonomous decision-making. The PM should progressively build their self-organization through gradual authority transfer.

questions.question: A team member was delegated responsibility for a deliverable but made decisions that caused problems. The PM had provided no guidance, checkpoints, or boundaries. Who is primarily responsible for the failure?
options: The team member who made poor decisions
The PM who delegated without proper setup
The sponsor who approved the delegation
questions.explanation: Delegation without clear expectations, boundaries, and checkpoints is abdication. The PM failed to set up the team member for success. Poor delegation setup is a PM failure, not a team member failure.

questions.question: What does "progressive delegation" mean?
options: Delegating to progressively more senior team members
Gradually increasing authority as capability is demonstrated
Moving through delegation levels in sequence
questions.explanation: Progressive delegation means starting with limited authority, verifying success, then expanding. It builds trust and capability incrementally rather than giving full autonomy before it's earned.

questions.question: A PM reviews every deliverable before it goes to stakeholders, even from senior team members with perfect track records. This is an example of:
questions.explanation: Reviewing everything regardless of track record is micromanagement. It signals distrust, creates bottlenecks, and wastes senior talent. Review should be risk-based‚Äîmore oversight for unproven work, less for proven performers.

questions.question: What is the relationship between authority and accountability?
options: Authority and accountability should be matched
They are independent of each other
questions.explanation: Authority and accountability must be balanced. Accountability without authority creates frustration (responsible but powerless). Authority without accountability creates chaos (power without consequences).

questions.question: A team member succeeds with a delegated decision. What should the PM do?
options: Document the success for the performance review
Recognize the success and consider expanding their authority
Verify they followed the correct process
Thank them and move on to other priorities
questions.explanation: Success with delegated authority should be recognized AND used to expand empowerment. Each success builds the case for more autonomy. Positive reinforcement encourages ownership.

questions.question: A senior VP bypasses the empowered technical lead and comes directly to the PM with technical requests. What should the PM do FIRST?
options: Handle the requests to maintain the executive relationship
Redirect the VP to the technical lead for technical matters
Escalate to the sponsor about the VP's behavior
Attend meetings with the VP and tech lead together
questions.explanation: The PM must protect team authority. First step is direct redirection‚Äîexplain that the tech lead owns technical decisions and route the VP appropriately. Don't enable the bypass by handling it yourself.

questions.question: A PM tells a team member "you're empowered to decide" but then overrules their decision. What is this called?
questions.explanation: Saying "you decide" then overruling creates false empowerment. It damages trust and teaches the team that empowerment isn't real. If the PM needs approval rights, be clear about it upfront.

questions.question: A team member makes a reasonable but ultimately wrong decision after being empowered. What should the PM do?
options: Coach them through what went wrong without removing authority
Document the failure for future reference
Take over the decision area to prevent future issues
questions.explanation: Reasonable decisions that don't work out are learning opportunities, not authority revocation triggers. Coach through the analysis, help them improve, maintain empowerment. Removing authority for honest mistakes kills empowerment culture.

questions.question: What is the main risk of giving a new team member full decision-making authority immediately?
options: They might make better decisions than the PM
They lack the context and experience to make good decisions
Other team members might be jealous
questions.explanation: New team members lack organizational context, relationship knowledge, and domain experience. Full authority too early leads to avoidable mistakes. Match authority to demonstrated capability.

questions.question: A PM notices they are the bottleneck for all decisions. What is the BEST solution?
options: Work longer hours to process decisions faster
Hire an assistant to help manage the decision queue
Define which decisions the team can make independently
Schedule daily decision meetings to batch approvals
questions.explanation: Being a bottleneck means too many decisions require PM involvement. The solution is reducing what needs approval‚Äîdefine decision rights so the team can act independently on appropriate matters. Don't optimize the bottleneck; eliminate it.

questions.question: According to PMI, what leadership approach is most aligned with team empowerment?
questions.explanation: Servant leadership focuses on serving the team's ability to deliver. It emphasizes removing obstacles, developing people, and enabling success‚Äîcore empowerment principles. PMI strongly favors servant leadership.

questions.question: In the PMI framework, the Empowerment Triangle consists of which three elements?
questions.explanation: The Empowerment Triangle: Authority (right to decide), Accountability (ownership of outcomes), Autonomy (freedom to choose approach). All three must be present for true empowerment.

questions.question: On the PMP exam, if a question describes an experienced team being micromanaged, the correct answer will likely involve:
options: Documenting the micromanagement for the lessons learned
Training the PM on leadership styles
questions.explanation: PMI favors empowerment. When capable teams are over-controlled, the answer typically involves increasing delegation, reducing oversight, or expanding decision authority. Match authority to capability.

questions.question: A question describes "responsibility without authority." What is PMI's expected response?
options: Provide the authority to match the responsibility
Reduce the responsibility to match available authority
questions.explanation: PMI expects PMs to resolve authority gaps. When someone is accountable for results, ensure they have the power, access, and resources to achieve those results. Fix the mismatch; don't accept it.

questions.question: What distinguishes a high-performing team from a functional team regarding empowerment?
options: High-performing teams need less PM involvement in decisions
High-performing teams have more experienced members
questions.explanation: High-performing teams self-organize and make decisions autonomously. The PM's involvement shifts from directing to enabling. Less PM involvement in daily decisions is a marker of team maturity and empowerment success.

document_detective.title: Document Detective - Empowerment Analysis

From: Rachel Martinez (Project Manager)
To: Kevin Park (Senior Developer)
Subject: Database Migration Ownership
Date: Monday, 9:15 AM

Kevin,

I'm assigning you to own the database migration workstream. This is critical to our Q2 launch.

You'll be responsible for delivering the migration on schedule and ensuring zero data loss. This is a high-visibility deliverable and leadership is watching closely.

questions.question: What empowerment elements are present in this delegation?
questions.answer: Present: Accountability ‚Äî Kevin is clearly responsible for delivery and outcomes; Visibility ‚Äî The importance is communicated.

questions.question: What empowerment elements are missing?
questions.answer: Missing: Authority ‚Äî No decision rights defined. Can Kevin approve overtime? Hire contractors? Make technical decisions? Escalate blockers?; Autonomy ‚Äî No clarity on approach. Must he follow a specific method or can he determine the approach?; Resources ‚Äî No mention of budget, team support, or tools; Boundaries ‚Äî No constraints defined (timeline, budget limits, scope boundaries); Support ‚Äî No checkpoint schedule or escalation path; Success Criteria ‚Äî "Zero data loss" is mentioned but no other success measures.

questions.question: What problems might Kevin encounter?
questions.answer: Authority Gap: Kevin will likely hit decisions he can't make (budget, staffing, timeline changes) and will have to keep coming back to Rachel; Setup for Blame: If it fails, Kevin was "responsible" but didn't have what he needed; Ambiguous Expectations: "On schedule" but no schedule provided; "zero data loss" but no testing/validation approach; No Support Structure: High-stakes deliverable with no checkpoints or help.

questions.question: How should this delegation be restructured?
questions.answer: Better Version should include: YOUR AUTHORITY (Technical approach decisions: You decide; Budget up to $15K: You approve; Schedule adjustments within 1 week: You decide, inform me; Staffing requests: Recommend to me, I'll approve; Scope changes: Bring to me for discussion), SUCCESS CRITERIA (Migration complete by April 15; Zero data loss verified by QA validation; Maximum 4 hours downtime; All rollback procedures documented and tested), SUPPORT (DBA team available for consultation; Weekly checkpoint: Thursdays 2pm; Escalation: Come to me immediately for blockers), BOUNDARIES (Stay within approved architecture; Follow security compliance requirements; Coordinate with QA on testing windows).

timeline_reconstructor.title: Timeline Reconstructor - Empowerment Journey
timeline_reconstructor.description: A project team's journey from dependency to empowerment has been scrambled. Arrange the events in the correct sequence, then analyze the empowerment transformation.

events.description: Team retrospective identifies "waiting for PM approval" as their biggest impediment. Average decision wait time is 2.3 days. Team velocity has dropped for three consecutive sprints.

PM creates and shares a Decision Authority Matrix defining three categories: Team Decides, Team Decides & Informs PM, and PM Approval Required. The matrix gives the team authority over 70% of daily decisions.
New PM (Jordan) joins the team, inheriting a group that checks every decision with their manager. The previous PM made all significant decisions personally.

Senior developer makes a technical decision independently for the first time. The decision works well. Jordan publicly recognizes the initiative in the team channel: "Great call on the caching approach. This is exactly the ownership I want to see."

Jordan analyzes the types of decisions that have been escalating to PM. Categorizes them as: truly need PM input (15%), could be team decisions (60%), and shouldn't even be decisions (25% - things with obvious answers).
Sprint velocity returns to historical levels. Team survey shows "authority to make decisions" score increased from 2.1 to 3.8. Team reports spending 40% less time waiting for approvals.

Jordan notices that team members still ask permission for clearly-delegated decisions. Realizes that authority on paper isn't the same as felt authority. Begins coaching team through decisions rather than making them.
Team holds their first sprint planning without PM task assignments. Team self-assigns work in 20 minutes. Two members volunteer for stretch assignments. Energy in the room is noticeably higher.

A delegated decision goes wrong‚Äîthe team chose a vendor that couldn't deliver. Instead of reverting to control, Jordan facilitates a blameless retrospective on what happened and what the team learned.
Jordan schedules 1:1s with each team member asking: "What decisions do you think you should be able to make that currently require my approval?" Documents the themes.

Team starts solving problems among themselves before involving Jordan. In one instance, they resolve a cross-team dependency conflict directly with the other team lead‚Äîsomething they would have escalated two months ago.

Jordan shares the empowerment journey at a PM community meeting. Other PMs are skeptical: "What if they make bad decisions?" Jordan responds: "They will. And they'll learn. My job is to create conditions for smart failure, not prevent all failure."
Jordan makes a deliberate choice to NOT attend the daily standup for one week. The team runs it themselves successfully. One member comments: "We actually got through it faster."

Team proposes changing their Definition of Done to include automated testing. Rather than approving or rejecting, Jordan asks questions to help them think through implications, then confirms: "This is your call. You own your quality standards."
Jordan formally transfers "process improvement" authority to the team. Instead of PM-approved retrospective action items, the team now implements changes directly and reports outcomes.

Wake-up Call ‚Äî Retrospective surfaces the problem
Assessment ‚Äî PM analyzes decision patterns
Discovery ‚Äî PM asks team what they want authority over

Milestone ‚Äî First self-directed sprint planning

analysis_questions.question: Why did Jordan start with analysis (Event E) before creating solutions?
analysis_questions.answer: Jordan needed to understand the REAL problem before solving it: Which decisions actually needed PM involvement? Which were being escalated unnecessarily? What was the root cause of the dependency? Key Finding: 60% of escalated decisions could be team decisions. This data justified the empowerment approach and helped design the Decision Authority Matrix. Principle: Diagnose before treating. Understand decision patterns before redistributing authority.

analysis_questions.question: What was significant about asking team members directly (Event J)?
analysis_questions.answer: Jordan asked: "What decisions do you think you should be able to make?" This was powerful because: Involved the team in designing their own empowerment; Identified decisions the team WANTED authority over; Created buy-in for the new model; Surfaced decisions Jordan might not have thought to delegate; Demonstrated respect for the team's judgment. Principle: Co-create empowerment. Don't just push authority‚Äîask what authority people want and can handle.

analysis_questions.question: Why was Event G (realizing paper authority isn't enough) important?
analysis_questions.answer: Jordan created the Decision Authority Matrix, but team members still asked permission. This revealed: Conditioned behavior: After years of checking everything, habits don't change overnight; Fear of failure: Authority means accountability; some feared making wrong decisions; Cultural lag: The old PM's norms were still in people's heads; Trust gap: Team didn't yet believe the empowerment was real. Jordan's Response: Shifted from "giving authority" to "coaching through decisions"‚Äîhelping people build confidence by working through choices together. Principle: Empowerment requires culture change, not just policy change. Coach people into confidence.

analysis_questions.question: How did Jordan handle the failed decision (Event I)?
analysis_questions.answer: The team made a bad vendor decision. Jordan's options: 1. ‚ùå Revoke authority ‚Äî "See, this is why I need to approve things"; 2. ‚ùå Blame the team ‚Äî "You should have known better"; 3. ‚úÖ Blameless learning ‚Äî "What happened? What did we learn?" Why this matters: If Jordan punished the failure, team would stop taking initiative; Empowerment REQUIRES permission to fail; Learning from mistakes builds better judgment than never making them. Principle: How you handle failure determines whether empowerment survives. Punish failure = kill empowerment.

analysis_questions.question: What did Event M (PM not attending standup) demonstrate?
analysis_questions.answer: Jordan deliberately stepped away for a week. Results: Team ran standup successfully; Actually finished faster; Demonstrated they didn't need PM presence. This validated: Self-organization was real, not performative; Team had internalized ownership; PM presence wasn't necessary for daily function; Empowerment had become the team's norm. Principle: Test empowerment by stepping back. If the team functions well without you, you've succeeded.

analysis_questions.question: What is the significance of the progression from individual empowerment (Event D) to team empowerment (Events N, O)?
analysis_questions.answer: Early Phase (Event D): Individual developer makes a decision; PM recognizes it specifically; Builds confidence one person at a time. Later Phase (Events N, O): TEAM proposes Definition of Done changes; TEAM owns process improvement authority; Collective ownership, not just individual delegation. The Progression: 1. Individual empowerment ‚Üí builds confidence; 2. Success recognition ‚Üí reinforces behavior; 3. Team sees what's possible ‚Üí culture shifts; 4. Team collectively owns decisions ‚Üí self-organization achieved. Principle: Start with individuals, scale to teams. Build momentum through visible wins.

analysis_questions.question: Why did Jordan wait until Event O to formally transfer process improvement authority?
analysis_questions.answer: Sequence mattered: 1. First, team demonstrated they could make decisions; 2. Then, team showed they could learn from failures; 3. Then, team proved they could run without PM; 4. FINALLY, formal authority transfer. Why wait? Premature formal authority without demonstrated capability = setup for failure; Team needed to BUILD to that level of ownership; Jordan needed evidence it would work; Formal transfer validated what was already happening. Principle: Formal authority follows demonstrated capability. Don't transfer ownership before readiness is proven.

analysis_questions.question: What made Jordan's approach to sharing (Event L) notable?
analysis_questions.answer: Other PMs asked: "What if they make bad decisions?" Jordan's response: "They will. And they'll learn. My job is to create conditions for smart failure, not prevent all failure." Key Insights: Accepted that failure is part of empowerment; Reframed PM role: enabler of learning, not preventer of mistakes; "Smart failure" = bounded risk, learning extracted; Control doesn't prevent failure‚Äîit just centralizes it. Principle: Empowerment means accepting that people will make mistakes. Your job is to make those mistakes survivable and educational.

delegation_level_matcher.title: Delegation Level Matcher
delegation_level_matcher.description: Match each scenario to the appropriate delegation level. Consider the team member's capability, the decision's risk/impact, and contextual factors.

situations.title: The New Graduate
situations.context: Maya just joined your team straight from university. She has strong theoretical knowledge but no practical experience. You need to assign her first real task: creating test cases for a small feature.
situations.decision: How much should Maya test? What approach should she use? What's the priority?
situations.why: First real task = no track record. Strong theory but no practical experience. Needs to learn organizational norms and standards. Low-risk task but formative experience.
situations.what_to_do: Maya, here's what I need: Create test cases for the login feature. Use our standard template (here it is). Cover these specific scenarios: [list]. Aim for 15-20 test cases. Check in with me tomorrow afternoon so I can review your progress and answer questions.
situations.goal: Set her up for success. Direct now so you can delegate later.

situations.title: The Proven Expert
situations.context: Derek has been your senior architect for three years. He has designed four successful system migrations with zero production incidents. A new migration project needs architecture decisions.
situations.decision: What architecture approach should be used for the data migration?
situations.why: Three years of proven track record. Four successful migrations. Zero incidents = demonstrated judgment. Within his domain of expertise.
situations.what_to_do: Derek, you own the architecture for this migration. Make the calls you think are right. I'd like a quick brief once you have a direction, but that's for my awareness, not my approval. Let me know if you hit any organizational obstacles I can help clear.
situations.goal: Trust earned through performance. Don't waste his time or yours with unnecessary oversight.

situations.title: The Risky Decision
situations.context: Your team is highly capable and has been self-organizing effectively for months. They want to adopt a new CI/CD tool that would require migrating all existing pipelines. The decision is technically complex and would affect three other teams.
situations.decision: Should we switch CI/CD tools and how should we implement it?
situations.why: Team is capable (could delegate normally). BUT: High impact decision (affects 3 teams). Cross-functional implications require coordination. PM can add value on organizational navigation.
situations.what_to_do: I trust your technical judgment on the tools. Let's work through this together‚Äîyou evaluate the technical options, I'll help navigate the cross-team implications. Final call on whether to proceed is yours, but let's make sure we've considered the broader impact together.
situations.goal: Capable team + high-impact decision = participate together. Don't take over, but don't be absent either.

situations.title: The Struggling Performer
situations.context: Raj has been on the team for a year. Lately, his work quality has declined‚Äîmissed details, incomplete deliverables, uncharacteristic mistakes. You've had one coaching conversation but haven't seen improvement yet.
situations.decision: How to approach the next assigned feature?
situations.why: Has capability (year of experience, previous good work). Currently struggling (recent decline). Needs closer support without micromanaging. Need to understand root cause while providing structure.
situations.what_to_do: Raj, here's the approach I'd like you to take for this feature, and let me explain why: [specifics]. I want to set you up for success here. Let's check in at the end of each day this week so I can help you stay on track. What's going on for you that might be affecting things?
situations.goal: Coach through the rough patch. Direct enough to ensure success, supportive enough to help recover.

situations.title: The Confident Junior
situations.context: Aisha has been on the team for four months and has picked things up quickly. She's eager and confident‚Äîsometimes overconfident. She just volunteered to handle a stakeholder negotiation that typically requires senior experience.
situations.decision: How should the stakeholder negotiation be approached?
situations.why: Four months = still developing. Eager and confident (good!). But possibly overconfident for this specific task. Stakeholder negotiation = high visibility, relationship risk. Good learning opportunity with appropriate support.
situations.what_to_do: Aisha, I love that you volunteered for this. Here's my recommended approach based on what I know about this stakeholder: [specifics]. I want you to lead it, but let's role-play the conversation first. I'll observe the actual meeting and we'll debrief after.
situations.goal: Channel enthusiasm into learning. Don't crush confidence, but ensure appropriate preparation for high-stakes situation.

situations.title: The Crisis Situation
situations.context: Production is down. Customers are impacted. The CEO is asking for updates every 15 minutes. Your team is highly experienced and knows the system well, but emotions are running high and multiple people are shouting different theories about the cause.
situations.decision: How do we diagnose and fix the production issue?
situations.why: Crisis = no time for consensus-building. Chaos = need single point of coordination. High stakes = wrong decision is very costly. Even experienced teams need direction in crisis.
situations.what_to_do: Stop. Here's what we're doing: Chen, you own database investigation‚Äîreport in 5 minutes. Priya, you're on network. Marcus, check application logs. Everyone else, stay off the production server. I'll coordinate communication. We'll sync every 10 minutes in this channel. Go.
situations.goal: Crisis leadership. Cut through chaos, assign clear roles, maintain coordination. Return to normal delegation when crisis passes.

situations.title: The Routine Decision
situations.context: Your team has been self-organizing effectively. A team member asks whether they should use JSON or XML for a configuration file format. There's no strong organizational standard, and either works fine.
situations.decision: JSON or XML for config files?
situations.why: Team is self-organizing. Low-impact decision. No significant constraints. Team member is asking out of habit, not necessity.
situations.what_to_do: You know what? You should decide this. It's your code. Use whatever makes more sense for the use case. You don't need my input on this.
situations.goal: Break dependency on unnecessary approval. Teach team that routine decisions are theirs.

situations.title: The Stretch Assignment
situations.context: Kim is ready for growth. She's been a solid performer for two years and has expressed interest in technical leadership. A medium-complexity project needs a technical lead‚Äînormally you'd assign a senior, but this could be Kim's development opportunity.
situations.decision: How should the technical work be organized and led?
situations.why: Development opportunity = some risk accepted. First time in role = needs support structure. Solid performer = has earned the chance. Medium complexity = bounded risk.
situations.what_to_do: Kim, I want you to lead this technically. You'll make the key decisions, but I'll be your thought partner‚Äîlet's talk through major choices together. I won't override you unless there's a serious issue. Check in with me twice a week, and come to me anytime you're stuck.
situations.goal: Stretch + support. Enough autonomy to grow, enough backup to succeed.

situations.title: The External Constraint
situations.context: Your team wants to adopt a new testing framework. They've researched it thoroughly and are confident it's the right choice. However, your organization has a Technology Standards Board that must approve new tools, and the process takes 6-8 weeks.
situations.decision: Should the team adopt the new testing framework?
situations.why: Team made a good recommendation. But organizational process exists for a reason. PM needs to navigate the approval process. Team can't bypass governance unilaterally.
situations.what_to_do: Great analysis on the testing framework. I agree it's the right technical choice. Here's the reality: we need Standards Board approval. Let's work together‚Äîyou prepare the technical justification, I'll handle the politics and scheduling. Your recommendation drives this, but we need to go through the process.
situations.goal: Support team decision through organizational constraints. PM adds value by navigating bureaucracy.

situations.title: The Reversible Experiment
situations.context: Your agile team wants to try a new retrospective format they read about. It's a bit unconventional but interesting. The "risk" is that one retrospective might not be as productive as usual.
situations.decision: Should the team try the new retrospective format?
situations.why: Low risk (one retro). Fully reversible (can go back next sprint). Team process = team decision. Learning opportunity even if it doesn't work.
situations.what_to_do: Try it. It's your retrospective. If it works, great. If not, you'll learn something. Let me know how it goes.
situations.goal: Empower experimentation. Reversible, low-risk changes don't need permission.

situations.title: The Interpersonal Conflict
situations.context: Two team members are having a conflict that's starting to affect team dynamics. One has complained to you privately. Both are experienced professionals, and you've encouraged them to work it out directly, but it's not improving.
situations.decision: How to resolve the conflict between team members?
situations.why: Direct resolution was attempted and failed. Conflict is escalating. PM intervention now appropriate. Need to guide without taking over entirely.
situations.what_to_do: I've watched you both try to work this out, and I appreciate the effort. Here's what I think we need to do: [specific approach‚Äîmaybe a facilitated conversation, clear working agreements, or defined boundaries]. Let me explain why I think this will help. I'll facilitate, but you both own making it work.
situations.goal: Step in when self-resolution fails. Coach through conflict, don't dictate the outcome.

situations.title: The Expert Disagreement
situations.context: Two senior technical experts on your team disagree about the right approach for a complex feature. Both have strong track records. Both have valid technical arguments. The team is stuck waiting for resolution.
situations.decision: Which technical approach should be used?
situations.why: Both experts are capable (normally would delegate). But they're deadlocked. Team is stuck, need resolution. PM can facilitate, add decision criteria, break tie if needed.
situations.what_to_do: You're both making valid points. Let's structure this: What are the key criteria we should use to decide? What's the risk profile of each approach? If you had to identify the ONE biggest concern with the other option, what is it? [Facilitate discussion] If you still can't agree after this, I'll make the call‚Äîbut I want your best input first.
situations.goal: Facilitate expert resolution. PM breaks tie only if necessary, doesn't substitute judgment for expertise.

empowerment_perspectives.description: Experience empowerment situations from different viewpoints. Each scenario shows how the SAME situation feels different depending on whether someone is empowered or controlled.

scenarios.title: The Technical Decision
scenarios.situation: A new feature requires choosing between two technical approaches. Both are viable. The team has a recommendation.

perspective_a.name: Jordan
perspective_a.internal_monologue:
We've been debating microservices versus monolith for the new feature. The team talked it through‚Äîwe're going with microservices. It'll be more work upfront, but we've done the analysis, and it fits our scaling needs.

I told Sarah [PM] our recommendation this morning. She asked a few good questions about deployment complexity, which made me think harder about rollback scenarios. Then she said, 'Makes sense. It's your call‚Äîyou're closer to the technical details than I am.'

That felt good. She trusted our judgment. And honestly, her questions made the decision better. I hadn't fully thought through the rollback scenario, so we added some safeguards.

I feel ownership over this. If it works, it's because WE made a good call. If it doesn't, I'll own that too‚Äîbut I know Sarah will help us course-correct rather than blame us.
experiences: PM as thought partner, not gatekeeper

perspective_b.name: Jordan
perspective_b.internal_monologue:
We've been debating microservices versus monolith for the new feature. The team talked it through‚Äîwe want microservices. We wrote up a detailed recommendation and sent it to Sarah [PM] three days ago.

Still waiting for approval.

I followed up yesterday. She said she's 'reviewing it' and has some concerns about 'complexity' but hasn't had time to discuss. Meanwhile, we can't start the work.

This happens every time. We have the expertise. We've done the analysis. But every technical decision has to go through Sarah, and she's not even a developer. I don't think she understands the trade-offs as well as we do, but she's the bottleneck.

What's the point of having six years of experience if I can't make a technical call? I feel like a junior dev waiting for permission.

A few of us have been updating our LinkedIn profiles. If I wanted to just execute someone else's decisions, I could do that anywhere.

scenarios.key_insight: Same person, same expertise, same recommendation. The difference is authority‚Äîand it changes everything about the experience and outcome.

scenarios.title: The First-Time Lead
scenarios.situation: A team member is given their first leadership opportunity on a small project.

perspective_a.name: Priya
perspective_a.internal_monologue:
When Marcus [PM] offered me the lead role on the dashboard project, I was terrified and excited. I've never led anything.

But the way he set it up made me feel like I could do this. He said, 'You'll make the key decisions. I'll be your thought partner‚Äînot your approver. Check in with me when you want to talk something through, but I won't second-guess you.'

First week, I had to decide on the team's working hours for the project. I was going to ask Marcus, but then I remembered: this is MY call. So I proposed core hours to the team and asked what worked for them. We figured it out.

I did check in with Marcus about the vendor selection‚Äîthat felt bigger. He asked good questions, helped me think through it, then said, 'Your call. What's your decision?' I chose Vendor B. He supported it.

The project delivered. Not perfectly‚ÄîI made some scheduling mistakes early on. But Marcus helped me see them as learning, not failures. He said, 'Every lead makes those mistakes the first time. Now you won't make them again.'

I feel like I actually LED something. It wasn't Marcus's project that I executed. It was mine.

perspective_b.name: Priya
perspective_b.internal_monologue:
Marcus [PM] said I'm the 'lead' on the dashboard project, but it doesn't feel that way.

Every decision comes back to him. I proposed core hours for the team‚Äîhe changed them. I recommended Vendor A‚Äîhe overruled me and went with Vendor B. I tried to adjust the timeline when we hit an issue‚Äîhe said no without explanation.

I've stopped making decisions. I just ask Marcus what he wants and do that. It's faster than proposing something just to have it overruled.

The worst part is, when I ask directly, he says, 'You're the lead, you decide!' But then when I decide, he undoes it. The message is clear: I'm 'lead' in name only.

The project is going fine, I guess. But I don't feel like I'm learning to lead. I'm learning to execute Marcus's vision while he pretends I'm in charge.

When people congratulate me on the project, I feel like a fraud. It wasn't really my work.

scenarios.key_insight: Development requires real authority with real consequences. Fake delegation doesn't build capability‚Äîit builds cynicism.
